summary: microbial etiology of community-acquired pneumonia is often unclear in clinical practice. population-based studies examining etiology and incidence are lacking. incidence of CAP requiring hospitalization was 20.6 cases per 10000 adults/year. the LUH provides secondary care for the inhabitants of Reykjavik and nearby towns. it also provides 90% of all intensive care in the country. inclusion criteria were a new chest x-ray infiltrate and 2 additional symptoms. an oropharyngeal swab was collected for culture prior to in-hospital antimicrobial treatment. results from physician-ordered etiological diagnostic testing were also included. urine antigens were tested using commercially available tests. data were compared using 2 and Fisher’s exact test as appropriate. risk factors were examined in conjunction with specific etiologic results. variables included were age, sex, any underlying disease, asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, ischemic heart disease, heart failure, diabetes mellitus type 2. data collection Potential participants were approached within 24 hours of admission and underwent a structured interview. results were: length of stay (LOS), admission to intensive care units (ICUs), assisted ventilation, and in-house mortality. results of real-time PCR for S pneumoniae and H influenzae were considered positive at a cycle threshold of 35 or less to exclude false-positive results due to carriage. informed consent was obtained from individual participants or proxy included in the study. 511 cases approached with suspected pneumonia, 15 (3%) chose not to participate and 496 gave consent. 123 cases did not meet criteria for pneumonia, and exclusion criteria were present in 63 cases. 310 admissions were included in this ICU, intensive care unit; PSI, pneumonia severity index; RSV. a recent prospective study from the united states showed that S pneumoniae accounted for 5% of pneumonia requiring admission compared with 20% in this study. a possible explanation may be that Jain et al [12] recovered high-quality sputum samples from only 12% of their participants compared with 31% in this study. smoking, a risk factor for both CAP and invasive pneumococcal disease decreased by 50% in the population in the intervening period [29] the decrease in S pneumoniae between these studies and the current one is also in line with the decline in rates of pneumococcal pneumonia during the last century. 107 (35%) patients reported receiving antibiotics before admission, similar to previous reports (11%–32%) [6, 7, 12, 34] prior antibiotic use was associated with detection of M pneumoniae. odds of identifying S pneumoniae were increased in patients without recent antimicrobial use. the lack of correlation of symptoms with etiology has been demonstrated previously. the lack of correlation of symptoms with etiology has been demonstrated previously and is confirmed by these results. patients with dual pathogens had a trend towards worse outcomes. but the number of patients was low and therefore a great potential for type II error. we chose to collect oropharyngeal samples for PCR analysis. clinical signs and symptoms were of limited use for identifying patients with a respiratory virus. LOS and rates of ICU admission and need for assisted ventilation were similar regardless of microbial etiology.
